steps.text: Check for responsiveness by tapping shoulders and shouting
Call 911 or have someone call immediately
Place heel of hand on center of chest between nipples
Push hard and fast: 2 inches deep, 100-120 compressions per minute
Give 2 rescue breaths after every 30 compressions
Continue until help arrives or person starts breathing
Check for responsiveness by tapping and calling loudly
Call 911 after 2 minutes of CPR if alone
Use one or two hands for chest compressions
Push about 2 inches deep at 100-120 compressions per minute
Give 2 rescue breaths after every 30 compressions
Continue until help arrives or child responds
Tap the bottom of feet and call the infant's name
Call 911 after 2 minutes of CPR if alone
Use two fingers on center of chest just below nipple line
Push about 1.5 inches deep at 100-120 compressions per minute
Give 2 gentle rescue breaths covering mouth and nose
Continue until help arrives or infant responds

name: Heart Attack
description: Myocardial infarction requiring immediate medical attention

steps.text: Recognize the warning signs: Chest pain or pressure (squeezing, fullness), pain radiating to arm/jaw/back/neck, shortness of breath, cold sweat, nausea, lightheadedness
Call 911 immediately: State 'possible heart attack.' Every minute counts - heart muscle is dying. Do not drive the person yourself unless no other option
Have person stop all activity: Help them sit or lie in comfortable position, typically semi-reclined. Staying still reduces heart's workload
Give aspirin if available: Ask 'Are you allergic to aspirin?' If not, give one regular aspirin (325mg) or four baby aspirin (81mg each) to CHEW, not swallow whole
Loosen restrictive clothing: Unbutton shirt, loosen belt and tie. This helps with breathing and reduces constriction on chest
Help with prescribed medications: If person has nitroglycerin, help them take it as prescribed. They may take up to 3 doses, 5 minutes apart
Monitor and prepare for CPR: Watch for loss of consciousness or stoppage of breathing. If person becomes unresponsive and isn't breathing normally, begin CPR immediately
Keep person calm: Anxiety increases heart's oxygen demand. Reassure them help is coming. Stay with them until EMS arrives and takes over

name: Cardiac Arrest
description: Heart has stopped beating - immediate CPR required

steps.text: Call 911 immediately
Begin CPR immediately with chest compressions
Send someone to get an AED if available
Apply AED as soon as available and follow prompts
Continue CPR between AED shocks
Do not stop until emergency services take over
Turn on the AED and follow voice prompts
Expose the chest and wipe dry if wet
Attach pads to bare chest as shown on pads
Ensure no one is touching the person during analysis
Press shock button if advised by AED
Immediately resume CPR after shock
